title: Carrera Slotcar Track Kurve K5 R5 / 7,5° with shoulders

description.text:
Update vom 13.07.2016
Hier sind die neuen Kurven. Bei den Älteren gab es einen Fehler mit dem Radius. Diese Dateien bitte nicht mehr drucken.

Eine K5 Kurve für die Carrera 132/124 Bahn mit Randstreifen. Die geteilten Schienen sind für Drucker mit kleinerem Druckbett und müssen nach dem Druck zusammen geklebt werden.
Als Stromleiter kann man welche aus einer Standardgeraden nehmen, ein wenig biegen und einfügen.

Update from 13th July 2016.
Here are the new curves. Among older there was an error with the radius. These files please stop printing.

An R5 curve for the Carrera 132/124 slot car track with shoulders. The split rails are for printers with a smaller Heatbed and must be glued together after printing.
The current rails can taken from a standard straight and bend a little.

title: GASB One - RC Flying wing fully printed (ONLY 9 PIECES GLUELESS)

description.text:
Ciao a tutti,
Hello everybody,

GASB One is a very simple printable flying wing

The wingspan of this model is 80cm (31,5 inch). All the parts of the model are able to fit into a standard 3D printer (19x19x16cm work size). The key points of this design are: very few pieces to be printed (9), cheapness (about 420g of PLA), easy assembly/disassembly/repairng (no glue) and good flier!

History:

  • On July 31th 2016 over the field of GASB in Padulle the flying wing version 4 flew. The first four takeoff attempts was spent to find the CG. This is located 145mm rear to the junction leading edges of the wings. As soon found the CG, the plane took off twice by beautiful flights. The final weight of the version 4 was 334g with all (battery, motor, receiver etc,,,).
  • The version 5 was a little heavier (358g) due the increment of the thickness to 0.32mm instead 0.3mm, the infill 3% instead 2% and canopy fixed by magnets. The weight was increased but the motor is able to manage properly. Was downloaded by over 10000 people. Downloadable here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2320788
  • The version 6 had apported several improvements. Here listed https://www.thingiverse.com/make:347302 first off all the servo 9g more standard and the internal structure into the wing (to print without infill)
  • The current version 7, due to the very great help received from Marco67 https://www.thingiverse.com/Marco67/about is a very big step award. The main improvement is the fact that the model not require glue. This means that, in case of damage, you can disassembly the plane and print just the part demaged. Also, the wings back to be solid, without internal structure, this help the beginner and allow to choise the setup fovourite. The canopy not requires magnets.

Here there is a video https://youtu.be/TYR0Yaah_4o

see also this https://youtu.be/TPNiDbek_nQ

Electronic:
Motor BE 1806 2300kv https://it.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=AS_20170718115454&SearchText=be1806+2300kv
ESC 30A https://it.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=AS_20170718115506&SearchText=esc+30a
2x servos 9g https://it.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=AS_20170718115721&SearchText=servo+9g
Propeller 6x4 https://it.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20171128154025&SearchText=propeller+6x4

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa rework i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

0 - 8%

Notes:

Please refer to the instruction manual

comments.text:
Ciao Carletto,
I have experienced rev 6 , great job , very semple , few parts .
I have good experience in flying rc model , this model is my first experience with printed model , very exciting !
I had problem in weight , 800 gr , and in barycenter , I modified the front part to move the 3S 2200mAH battery forward, I added a strong hook to let the take off by a elastic .
to compensate for the weight i used a SunnySky X2212 1400 kV motor with a foldable 9x5 propeller.
I made three flights , during the last I experience a stall , corkscrew and crash.
Since I expected asymmetric wing stall i added turbuletors on the external wing but it did'n work
What is your experience ? have you experience the same catastrofic event ?
To overcame this problem I want to made a project change and apply a negative twist to the wing , 3 degree , in order to prevent stall of the tip of one wing ?
What do you thik ?
To do this change i need to made a new model of the wing , for this scope may I know which is the wing profile have you used ?
Generally speking I have found a lot of informations about how to print your model but very little about design of the model , example have yoy used xflr5 or otrer means to define wing cord , wing tapering ,wing swept , etc ?
Best regards
Roberto
comments.author: roberto52

comments.text:
Ciao Roberto,
il modello è basato sul profilo del progetto Zagi 10. In rete puoi trovarlo facilmente. Normalmente io stampo più leggero e non ho problemi di baricentro o di stallo. Nello sviluppo del tuttala ho rotto diversi modelli soprattutto all'inizio, sia per inesperienza nel lancio a mano, sia nella ricerca del baricentro. Adesso il modello è molto stabile e difficilmente crasha. Se ristampi ti consiglio di usare la revisione 7 che ti permette di montarlo senza colla in modo che ristampi solo la parte che ti si è rotta.

comments.text:
Hello again Carletto73.
I have read somewhere on the net that to calculate what motor is required to drive an rc aeroplane, it was stated, take the rc aircraft total weight, and find a motor that has a thrust amount in grams, more than the weight of the total aircraft weight!
To me it seems a good theory, reason why is that using your motor and prop for this 3d printable aeroplane, the motor specs state that for an 11.1 volt 3s battery and your chosen propeller, you can pull 390 grams thrust of weight, and the total of your printed rc aeroplane with all parts come to 358 grams, hence your plane can still pull that 358 grams and is still fast enough from the videos that I have seen of your plane in action.
What do you think regarding this theory ? To me, it seems that if this proves to be true, which it does seem so to me so far, then its the easiest way to calculate what motor you need and if it will be strong enough to carry the weight.

comments.text:
Ciao Paolo,
come puoi vedere alla penultima foto di questo link: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:248630, ho fatto diverse esperienze su dove dividere il corpo centrale, Il problema nel tagliarlo sulle superfici a contatto delle due ali è che il successivo incollaggio con la parte frontale, non viene perfetta (usando la colla ciano, non appena le due parti si toccano non sei più in grado di fare degli aggiustamenti), ed a sua volta l'incollaggio delle ali al corpo non è perfetto con il risultato di un montaggio precario ed esteticamente molto brutto. La soluzione migliore, secondo me e seguendo anche i suggerimenti di altri utenti che hanno il tuo stesso problema è tagliare il file STL alla quota massima da te stampabile. La parte finale del corpo, quella vicino al motore, non ha alcuna funzione "accessoria", puoi tagliarla dei millimetri che ti serve (fino ad arrivare al basamento del motore). L'unico piccolo inconveniente è che di fronte all'elica ci sarebbe una superficie piatta il che può provocare qualche piccola inefficienza e rumore del motore, ma questo è molto comune nei modelli in depron. Inoltre, non fidarti della quota che repetier assegna al pezzo, se noti gli ultimi mm del cubo che riserva al pezzo, sono vuoti! Per pura informazione specifico che questo è dovuto al fatto che per ovviare ad un errore che mi da il mio CAD (?!?), ho dovuto lasciare un filo di un millesimo di millimetro (che lo slicer non considera) nel bordo di uscita dell'ala (che è qualche millimetro, più alto, rispetto al pezzo).
Ciao, aspetto una foto del tuo GASB One e le tue impressioni sull'oggetto e su come vola.
Carlo

comments.text: This kind of informations are missed since is not the model for beginner. Usually to start to flight they take a glider bigger and slow. I've some doubt that a beginner can start from a flying wing. My suggestion is mount all, and give the model an expert to test it. Anyway, you need an ESC 20A to drive the motor, this have to be provided to BEC to feed the receiver (find on aliexpress ESC with BEC), 2 servos 3,7g, and a receiver.Ch1 first aileron servo, Ch2 second aileron servo and Ch3 ESC. The flight controller is not needed. My suggestion is ask to a forum on your country how wiring the GASB One, I hope that is better to my english :(

comments.author: Carletto73

comments.text: For Ch1 or Ch2 left or right is indifferent because is managed by the radio. If you have a radio programmable you have to use elevon function that mix the left right up and down command properly to manage the aileron on flying wing. If you don't have a programmable radio, instead, you have to use an external mixer for elevon management.

comments.text:
ciao carletto73, bel tuttala! ti faccio solo un paio di critiche se permetti: innanzitutto perché ha messo gli alettoni così interni? se li metti sull'esterno dell'ala lavora molto meglio, serve meno deflessione della parte mobile e il servo è sollecitato meno. altra cosa, ma forse è la foto che inganna, meglio dare più segmenti alla curva per avere un profilo più lineare
ultima cosa, l'infill in quel modo non serve quasi a nulla. ti consiglio di prendere spunto dall'interno dell'ala dei modelli di 3dlabprint, guadagneresti in peso e robustezza
comments.author: Dea90

comments.text:
Ciao Dea90 e grazie dei commenti. Per gli alettoni ho già ricevuto alcune critiche al campo volo. Diciamo che sono in quella posizione per poter mettere i servo più avanzati possibile per fare in modo che il CG sia rispettato senza mettere piombi. Sono lunghi 160mm, potrei arrivare a 200mm con la mia stampante cmq i primi voli non sono stati malaccio. Diciamo che con gli alettoni in quella posizione è leggermente sordo ai comandi ma non più di avere un esponenziale un po' altino. Altro problema a portarlo fuori è che l'ala si restringe molto e diviene piu difficile garantire robustezza. Per il profilo ti garantisco che è abbastanza curvo le foto non rendono anche perché si vede l'infill in trasparenza. Il parametro FACETRES è settato a 10 le spigolature che rimangono sono dovute alla risoluzione di cura, del fw della stampante e dai sui limiti hw. Per l'infill passando dal 2% al 3 l'ala è diventata molto più robusta. Prima era difficoltoso il lancio a mano senza danneggiare l'ala nel punto dove la si stringeva con la mano. Sto pensando anche di ristampare al 2% ma aggiungendo una pinna per poter prendere il modello da sotto durante il lancio, proteggerebbe inoltre anche l'elica all'atterraggio. Cmq darò un occhiata ai modelli che mi ha detto, si può sempre migliorare☺
Se lo stampi fai la versione 5 che è l'ultima. La sua forma è spettacolare con la canopy.
Ciao Carlo
comments.author: Dea90

comments.text:
Ciao a tutti,
oggi il modello ha volato ed anche bene con condizioni meteo proibitive almeno per un collaudo.
Nei primi quattro tentativi di decollo il modello è caduto al lancio. Una volta trovato il centro di gravità corretto invece il decollo non è stato più un problema.
Nella prima caduta il modello ha picchiato forte di punta e si è spezzato in due all'altezza di un servo sulle ali. E' stata eseguita una rapida riparazione al campo con ciano e fasciatura con nastro rinforzato. il modello così riparato ha subito altre tre cadute al lancio ed ha poi fatto due voli regolari.
Con la batteria 3 celle 450mAh ed elica 5x3 ha volato per 4 minuti e la batterua non era ancora scarica.
Il modello è veloce ma anche un buon planatore. Occorre apportare due modifiche. La prima è quella di fare il vano batterie ed elettronica più avanti rispetto ad oggi di 3 centimetri per avere il centro di gravità a 145mm dietro l'incrocio del bordo di entrata delle ali. la seconda modifica è quella di costruire sotto la pancia una pinna irrobustita per lanciarlo da quella posizione anzichè dalli ali, questo perchè le ali essendo così sottili sono anche fragili e tendono a rompersi se durante il lancio si stringe troppo con la mano. Aggiungerò anche la canopy ed i riferimenti per il centro di gravità.
Il peso finale è di 334 grammi.

Holder for a SMA or RP-SMA pigtail cable in place of the original antenna. Apart from popping the original antenna out, no other modifications to the shell are needed (so no dremel). Connector is firmly held in place, and prevented from rotating (so easy to screw on or off antenna). Furthermore this should print OK on almost all printers without need for support material.

OpenSCAD source files included. Printed on my printer things fit rather snug, but this might differ on other printers. In that case, feel free to change some measurements in the source files.

Print Holder.stl once normal, once mirrored. Print Clip.stl once, and optionally print Cap.stl.
Put the two holders over the plug, put in the antenna hole, and put on the clip on the inside. If needed (and the connector is long enough), put the cap over it, and screw on the nut belonging to the connector. (Step-by-step included as pictures)

Alternatives, no shell modification:

  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1063873
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579504
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1631595

Alternatives, dremel or cutting required:

  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213959
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:733022
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1130405

UPDATE 26-07-2016:
Update the Holder.stl and Holder.scad, the hex nut inlay rotation is now fixed, and the geometry is slightly changed for a much better fit.

description.text:
I almost forgot to put these on ere....

simple direct fitment corner mounts with level adustment.

no cutting, no drilling no trimming, just print 4, slot on each corner and screw heated bed down on springs, nice and solid with zero faffing about with hacksaw blades and drills and no need to damage the original print bed.

works with mk2,mk2b & mk3alu reprap heated bed (tested).

requirements -
4x m2x20mm screws/bolts
4x springs (specfic heated bed springs from eGay or even 4 from some cheapo clicker biros will do the job)

print from either PLA or ABS (whichevers your poison), Ive not had heat propergating down the screws or springs at anywhere near enough to effect the parts and thats even with the Mk3 Alu heated bed running at 120°c

enjoy.

Printer:

colido printrite diy ramps1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

30%

title: Dungeon Explore Card Tray

description.text:
KICKSTARTER ALERT! - Our good friend and fellow designer Nathan Smith over at Maker Games has made some really cool modular dungeon tiles and we at Ill Gotten Games were lucky enough to get an advance copy. These are perfect for quick (or, if you're like us, random) dungeons for any game that uses 28mm/Heroic scale miniatures. Go check it out now and drop a pledge, you'll be glad you did!

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Airsoft KWC Uzi chest holster (hardcase)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
AIRSOFT ACCESSORY

Update - 06/07/2016

  • Added one more slotted tab for attaching the sling, getting it closer to the way a GoPro Chesty is attached.

  • Cleaned the previous slots to remove potentially weak parts and make the sling routing smoother.

  • Added one of the backplates needed to spread the slings (some more work to do on that part)

I won't work anymore on the main body until I had an opportunity to print it, so I can confirm if the fit is right or not (as final dimensions depends on part shrinkage, nozzle diameter, etc...)

Object description :

This is a first attempt at making a chest mounted hardcase holster for a KWC Uzi as I couldn't find any to buy. I didn't try to print it yet, and I think I could add one more mounting bracket for one more sling (I tried to recreate the way a GoPro chesty is attached). You have ~45° angle from the right to put in/take out the gun. It's supposed to be a snug fit, but can't try it yet.

I'm still a novice at modeling too, so don't be too hard on me :p

This may not look impressive, but I created it in virtual reality using an HTC Vive and an app called SculptrVR. It was pretty amazing to be able to build an object floating in mid air and walking around it.

Here's a video (not of me) showing how SculptrVR works: https://youtu.be/8HgpL5-e1LM

It wasn't immediately clear how to export scenes from SculptVR. Turn your left hand palm up to see the secondary menu where you can save, save to obj, etc using right hand to point at buttons. (also there's no confirmation when you save)

The obj file then gets saved to: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\sculptrvr\SculptrVR\SculptrVRSaves

It saves in inches so when you re-save it as an stl make sure you convert from inches to mm or else it will be tiny.

comments.text: Im liking this purely on the fact that you created this in VR. Surely, this is one of the first in our world. But, in time, this will become the standard creation tool and this object will be a historical reminder of the simplicity of our past. One day this will be quaint.

title: Brush & Safety Razor Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: So for awhile now i've had one of the little metal stands to hang my brush and razor from, but it takes up alot of space, I suddenly realized I could build a better setup and hang it from the underside of one of the shelves in my medicine cabinet.

Print both parts, use a large woodscrew or a tap and machine screw (I'm using extra M5 screws from my Mendelmax build, the hanger hole is 5.4mm dia. the mounting bracket hole is 4.2mm dia. and 15mm deep) to secure the parts together, use small woodscrews or bolts to secure the hanger to the underside of a shelf. Magnets might also possibly work for those of you with metal shelves, or double sided tape for glass shelves. I used a two-screw mount as my first attempt, but thought it was a tad flimsy so I made a three-screw mount and included that. Feel free to play around with it yourselves. EDIT: Thav seems to have found a potential issue with the hanger, so I increased the height of the catch nubs so things wouldn't fall off so easily and uploaded it as v3. His version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29504 Thanks.

print_settings.Notes:: Frame : 0.3mm 20%+ infill

description.text:
There are many, many designs and I have printed as many, but its difficult to find one that's just right! (for me at least).

So, I designed this Spool Holder with following considerations:

  • All parts must be printable.
    (I don't want to go out and buy threaded rods, bearings, poles, screws or anything)

  • No assembly required.
    (Also I dont want to measure and cut or saw rods, poles, pipes or anything)

  • For rigidness, the frame must be printed as single thing. no mechano like assembly

  • The spindle must be also printed, as I don't want to use a rod or pipe that constantly need to be secured.

  • Design must be simplistic, yet functional design

  • It must be able to support different hub/mount hole diameters

  • It must not fall apart or topple over.

It was designed primarily for ESUN, Verbatim and Protopasta spools, so if you have a different size, let me know, and I'll add some variations

I suggest that you place the frame on a high friction surface, to prevent it from sliding. I use a rubber mat

Update 3 - 2017-01-09

Added wider frame (95mm) for Verbatim 1kg spools
Also added spool 51mm for this frame

Update 2 - 2016-11-30

Modified spindle to print easier - added flat bar to bottom of spindle for better adhesion to build plate, Also made variations with support

3 spindle/hub sizes
52 = 52mm
54 = 54mm
56 = 56 mm

Notes:

  • Frame : 0.3mm 20%+ infill

  • Spindle: 0.25-0.3mm 20%+ infill

QAV-R GoPro Session mount with 30 degrees of tilt.

Same design as my QAV210-180 GoPro Session mount, only this one fits the QAV-R (middle standoff is 3mm more to the back of the frame).

I wanted another faction/army for the RTS-style wargame I'm creating, hence the Oktober Guard (the Warsaw Pact equivalent to the Joes). I realize that this is a silly looking machine but I copied the idea from the comic books I read as a kid.

The chassis and gun are printed with supports. The pieces are pretty small so they shouldn't take too long to clean up. The tires are printed with the 'hubcaps' up and then glued to the body.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and to make silly little toys. It's actually you people that are "the real American heroes".

I created these files and they are free to download. Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”. Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model. You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. print_settings.Notes:: I recommend to print with 100 % infill for strength, but you may lower the infill if the harness is mainly for show.

description.text:
I do body harnesses for BDSM, cosplay and animal roleplay purposes. For the central join point I used metal rings. But they are expensive and because they're round, they wrinkle the straps.

So I created new plastic "rings": Square for the bottom of harness and pentagonal for the top part. They are strong enough and look better.

The components are intended for 30 mm straps. The buckles and other plastic components are store bought. It is possible to 3D print them, but they're readily available and pretty cheap, so there is no need to print them. If you do want to print them, there are models on Thingiverse as well.

The following parts are available:

  • Hollow version ("rings" as on photographs)
    • harness_5.stl - pentagonal top part
    • harness_4.stl - square bottom part
  • Full version (solid construction and holes for straps)
    • harness_5F.stl - pentagonal top part
    • harness_4F.stl - square bottom part with four holes (for additional strap going between the legs)
    • harness_3F.stl - square bottom part with only three holes

title: Oktober Guard U.R.S.A. Command HQ (GI Joe)

description.text:
I wanted another faction/army for the RTS-style 1:100 scale wargame I'm creating, hence the Oktober Guard (the Warsaw Pact equivalent to the Joes) vehicles and equipment. I needed an HQ unit but couldn't find anything online/canon, so I ended up just making this up.

The U.R.S.A. Mobile Command HQ is made of four vehicles that drive to the desired location and then deploy. Two vehicles back up to each other and open, creating the HQ platform. The tanker truck (probably containing some environmentally unfriendly fuel, this is the 1980s after all) is used to power the generator that runs the base and also refuel any mobile units operating in the area. The long range mortar is used for fire support, based on radar data gathered by the HQ. The top of each tractor cab has a small gun for defensive fire.

To make the entire base as intended you'll need:
4 tractors
1 fuel tank
1 mortar base and 1 mortar
2 of the closed bunkers
1 each of the 'open' bunkers. Sorry, wasn't worth my time to make them actually open and close.
None of these pieces require supports for printing.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and to make silly little toys. It's actually you people that are "the real American heroes".

I created these files and they are free to download. Since I did not copy any existing IP I can set the permissions as I choose.
If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission. Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

This seals the end of a piece of "100mmx50mm" (which is a metric approximation) rectangular downpipe, closing the ends for a hydroponic run. It is parametric and can be rescaled to suit larger pipes, or indeed anything with a rounded rectangle profile that needs plugging!

Make sure they fit. Print one for each end. Cut square & clean ends of the pipe. Squirt silicone sealant, epoxy or similar into the groove on the endpiece. Mallet onto the end of the pipe and leave for adhesive to set. If it leaks, dry it and varnish it.
These endpieces were printed in Ivory PLA from Diamond Age Solutions Ltd. on a Simplified Kiwi Mendel.

title: Cath Lab Transluscent EKG Cable Manager

description.text: MacLab does not make a cable manager for EKG leads that are translucent. Using 3d slash and then Tinkercad I remixed these for 5 leads. At first I used superglue to hold the flat plate in place, but am remixing this only to provide four sets per print and to use a small 3mm screw to hold in place just in case a lead needs replacing. These work best if there is a snug fit for the wires closest to the patient side (it will need to be scaled down) and if printing regular size these keep the leads from bunching up and tangling when not in use. I use one small and one large for each set.

I wanted another faction/army for the RTS-style wargame I'm creating, hence the Oktober Guard (the Warsaw Pact equivalent to the Joes) vehicles.

I needed the Oktober Guard to have a helicopter and I didn't really like the semi official toy I saw online. Besides, Russian helicopters don't get more iconic than the Hind so I modeled this after that helicopter. I didn't know much about them except what you see in Rambo movies, but turns out this thing is enormous; basically a fast flying tank. It is modeled 1:100 scale but I had to make the rotors 1/4" smaller in diameter than they are supposed to be to fit on my print bed.

The chassis is printed with supports which are difficult to clean off. Be very careful when removing supports from around the weapon pylons as they will break off without a lot effort. (I used a needlenose pliers.)
The gun pod is printed upside down with supports (simple to clean off) and glued to the underside.
Main rotor (no supports) can be put on and taken off for storage.
Tail rotor and weapons print without supports and are glued in place. The weapons just press onto the pylons.
The stand is something I am experimenting with. I glued a magnet to the underside of the helicopter and put another one on the stand.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and to make silly little toys like these. It's actually you people that are "the real American heroes".

I created these files and they are free to download. Since these files are based off of a well known physical object (and because I did not copy anyone's IP) I don't really have any restrictions on how you can use them. If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission (and as you might be able to tell - it kinda annoys me).

author: remz

title: 90mm Spindle Mount, DW618, Bosch 1617, Porter Cable  892, 690
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This unit remains untested- I suggest printing about 5mm of the piece, canceling the print, and testing fit-up before trying a complete print.

Ordered the wrong spindle mount for my R7 router kit- 3d printer to the rescue! This will fit most 2 1/4hp router units- 90mm. The part that mounts to the c-beam is very tight. There is no room for over extrusion of filament, and your printer must be running perfectly, dimension wise. Even with perfect settings you may have to do a bit of preparation in order to get it to fit. There was no way around this- the tolerances are a b#%$h. Print with at least 65% to 70% infill, 100% would be best... Screw holes are all M5- the two M5 (60-65mm) holes for the compression screws take M5 (nylon) nuts that slide into the slots on the right side of the mount- do NOT forget these, as the plastic will likely strip. The two holes that mount to the c-beam take low profile, 15mm, M5's with t-slot nuts.

Testing and pictures coming soon.

description.text:
A pillbox for Cobra infantry. The actual toy was just half a bunker so you could move the people around inside, but this is modeled as a complete cylinder with a door in the back.

Printing is pretty simple; the bunker is made without supports and the rocket is printed with. Since it's so small you can use a nail clipper to clean up the supports.
The file was created full scale, I modeled it so that it was optimized when printed at 25%. Unless you stay in that range it may have too much or too little detail.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace and freedom and to make silly little toys. It's actually you people that are "the real American heroes".

I didn't sand it cause I'm lazy.
This is a drawing of the Solarbotics GM3 Gearmotor.  These little motors are awesome and are used in a variety of projects.  I use them to build extruders for my RepRap machine.

You'll want to use this drawing as a basis for your own work.  Use the drawing for an idea of where the motor will fit, its size, and where the mounting holes.
If you're doing a lasercut design, you can put the motor where you want it, then cut out the mount holes and your motor will mount perfectly.
The drive shaft is also the proper size to be cut on a Epilog 35W laser and come out nice and snug.

In case you want to use the Nanotec stepperdriver boards for your 3D, e.g. RepRap, printer, this board might be of use. It provides for the recommended capacitor and connectors for (AMP) Power, steppermotoer, and Min/Max sensors. Use it for the X, Y, Z and (optionally) extruder steppermotors.
The nanotec board provides microstepping (1/8 or 1/16 for SMC11 or SMC11-2 respectively) The connector pin layout is conform the gen3 electronics motherboard as used in the RepRap and MakerBot 3D printers. Attached is a PCB version as well as a Veroboard layout.

comments.text: Oh, one suggestion to improve it (even further). You could extend the stepper output pin towards the side of the boards to allow (optional) screw terminals there.

description.text:
Whether these are improved or not remains to be seen...  
Herringbone style gears, 1.25 Mod, 20 degree PA, and 25 degree helix.  
The motor gear is 9T the extruder gear is 28T for a ratio of 1 : 3.1  
The large gear prints fine, 1 shell and 100% infill, 0.2mm layer height.   
The smaller gear has been a bit more problematic. Printing it on its own was unsuccessful, because the part is small, the heat builds up and the top ends up mushy. To combat this I printed the pair together oriented with the gear teeth flat on the platform, support material is needed. This made me a functioning small gear, however there are still a few wobbles in the teeth that I will try and sort out.

description.text:
Here you can find table flips for any occasion! Flip the tables whether you’re angry, sad or happy! Often expressed as a Japanese meme in emoticons, called kaomoji, this tiny table will certainly help you express your mood in the real world when ever you need to.

The simple instructions of how to use this device are given on both the top and bottom sides of the table describing proper use.

On the Top: (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻ (indicating the flip technique)

On the Bottom: (ヘ･_･)ヘ┳━┳ (indicating the table reset)

So go ahead and print yours today and never be with out the soothing stress relief of flipping a table.

Watch my video on the build and the table in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FisrsE7wGY8

"Not recommended for anyone with a heart condition or fear of tables."

Printer:

flashforge

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

fast

Infill:

40%

Notes:

This model does much better with infill above 40% to aid in the strength needed to survive intense flipping. Printing in PLA I have found that fast prints really well and medium provides only a minimal difference, your milage may vary depending on printer and filament.

No raft is needed but I do recommend a skirt as it helps with better flow into the main body print.
some lines due to my bed needing more cleaning and possibly a new release mat.

built in 123D with simple shapes for optimum flip rate and spin. Corners of the table were rounded to provide a better bounce on a corner strike. Round legs were used to provide the best chance of surviving multiple flip usage. ASCII was subtracted via text placement and go about 5 layers deep to allow for painting if desired or remixing to use a different filament for a dual head print.

comments.text:

Not really a thing, but a simple technique to handle filament spools. This solution eliminates problems with dust and helps to keep moisture out of your plastic.  
Shown in the photo, I decided to run the filaments to my 3D Touch printer externally. This reduces the sharper filament bends you have to deal with if you put the spools on the spindles provided with the 3D Touch and BFB3000. So, it occured to me that instead of making new spindles or spool holders to mount them outside the printer, it might be possible to keep the filament (and the dessicant) inside the original plastic bag it comes in. I just cut a small hole in the bag and run the filament into the tubes that guide it to the printer's extruders, then stick the end of the tube into the hole in the bag and seal it up with some blue tape. It's not truly air-tight because the bags usually have a few tiny holes in them anyway (if you find them you can put a piece of tape over them), but it is much, much better than having your filament out in the open air.   
This technique means that the extruder drive of the printer must be strong enough to spin the spool in the plastic bag. But it really doesn't take much force to do that, mainly because the friction between the plastic bag and the tiny area of the spool rims that they rest on is very small. The 3D Touch has no problem pulling the filament off the spool and turning the spool. No worries about dust! Less worries about moisture!  
When you remove a filament you can work the filament back onto the spool by turning the spool from the outside of the bag. Grab the spool with one hand, slide the bag, bunching it up a bit in the opposite direction you want to turn the spool with the other hand, release the first hand and slide it in the same direction, grab again and turn it the other way -- not a great explanation, but the idea is to work the spool around using the bag sort of like gloves -- once you get the hang of it, it's easy. when the filament is wound back up on the spool, use a piece of tape or a clip to hold the end of the filament to the rim of the spool. Then seal the hole in the bag with tape for storage.  
The sad thing about this is there's nothing to print!

comments.text: This gave me an idea... build a spool holder out of PVC pipes, get a larger bag, put the spool(s) on the PVC spool holder, and then put the spool holder inside the bag! Just tape a couple of tubes on the bag for the filament and good to go! Free rolling spools of filament in a humidity free environment! Of course, add a pack of desiccant inside the bag for even more protection.
comments.author: nlnpereira

comments.text:
I tried this on a Smartrap, which is noteworthy for using a weak, direct drive extruder. I don't use a bowden cable in my setup because I haven't enough tubing to spare. It works just fine without it. To further reduce issues with moisture I pack a few silica gel packets inside the bag before sealing it up again.
One important thing to note is that the bags should be placed below the extruder somewhere, as shown in the picture. I was having issues when feeding filament from the side, which makes more intuitive sense with the smartrap. There was just too much friction between the spool and the bag for this system to reliably feed plastic without user intervention.

Yes, I thought this might not work with a lot of extruders where the filament runs perpendicular to a hobbed drive shaft. The 3D Touch printer (like mine) drives the filament almost parallel to the drive screw, being grabbed by many threads of the screw, so there is a whole lot more contact, and consequently it is capable of pulling the filament quite hard.
And yes, I put silica gel packs in the bags.
Since I started buying PLA from ProtoParadigm I haven't had any problems running the filament the way it was designed to run, i.e., with the spools resting on spindles on the bottom inside of the printer and taking a minimum size bend with a radius of about 2 or 2.5 inches. The problems I had with the original BFB branded filament was that it was too brittle and kept breaking at that smallest radius. That is why I reduced the bends of the filament tubes by running them outside the printer and came up with the 'in the bag' idea. I don't need to do that anymore with this less brittle PLA. I have yet to have the filament from ProtoParadigm break during a print even when routed the original 'BFB' way.

author: Kombater

description.text:
This simple little thing is meant to mount to a cabinet panel adjacent to a fridge door, to keep the fridge door closed when you want it closed, and to keep tiny humans from drinking the ketchup and salad dressing.  
None of the mounting touches the fridge at all, so you don't have to drill holes in or stick adhesive to your fridge.  
For safety purposes, this lock does not auto-engage when the fridge door shuts (like the old latching fridges) but needs the disk rotated toward or away from the fridge to lock and unlock.  It can be mounted at a height that makes it easy to use for older kids, but unreachable to ketchup-drinkers.  
You'll need 3 short screws about 4mm in diameter.  The screw that holds the disk to the anchor can be tightness-adjusted to make the disk harder or easier to move.  
Please scale by 10x to print as I am a failure at file unit sizes.

author: chris262

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!
customized with 3D Slash!

This tool holder will mount in place on the Z platform in place of the extruder allowing you to cut shapes out of paper vinyl or other thin material without much effort.  It does require a very level bed and I recommend cutting on a cut down cutting mat.
This was designed to hold a leading brand craft cutter's blade holder. 
Turn you MakerBot into a "ShopSmith" type multi-tool!

1) Print
2) Assemble (2x 8-32 flat head and 2x 8-32 nut required (sorry but I have a big bag of 8-32 screws and nuts and want to use them) Use Thing-o-Matic Gcode Inkscape Plugin to generate G-code - be careful to not crash the tool into you build platform. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16424 UPDATE I removed the original design and uploaded a beefier one. This one doesn't rock on my machine and with a sharp blade it can cut nicely. I tried it out on the Hack-A-Day logo as a proof of concept. It works good. Needed Parts:
2x 8-32 flat head machine screw and nut
Cutting mat or similar adhesive surface
Cutting tool holder and sharp cutting blade. If the blade is dull the paper will tear. I haven't tried anything heavier than printer paper in it but I would guess it wouldn't be a problem to cut craft paper or vinyl so long as the blade sharp.

comments.text: i made my own variation of this for the quickfit xcarriage for a prusa. surprisingly is a lot less forgiving than a filament extruder. the height needs to be perfect or you dig into the mat or miss the paper - you basically have less than one paper heights worth of error!
comments.author: rrhb

comments.text: Agreed. Â It relies on a bed that's been dialed in with a caliper. Â The design of the paper cutting machines like Cricut are such that they only move the cutter along one axis and that axis is parallel to the rods it moves on. Â However with a really level bed (perhaps glass would work great too), it is possible to do. Â The other thing that held is if your bed is adjustable and mounted on springs so it has a little give - then you can press a little harder without ripping up the paper.

Range carte

This is a holder/mount for a RLR Products radiator overflow bottle for KTMs. This will fit most KTM motorcycles from 2007 to current. I think it will fit most of the new Husqvarnas, as well. Instead of having to mount the bottle in the airbox where you can't see the level or might not have the room, this puts the bottle under the carburetor/EFI (fuel injector) and right above the chain guide. You just need a longer bolt for the top chain guide (1/4 inch longer). You remove the bolt, put this in place, put the new longer bolt in and tighten it, place the bottle in it, route your hoses, and fill it all up as the original directions say. I have two of these made (2008 KTM 530exc and a 2014 500exc) with over 3,000 hard off-road miles on each with no problems. Enjoy and Braaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaap on!

title: Hampton Bay Solar LED Path Light Anchors

description.text:
These lights come with a stake type anchor to be used in dirt or sand. These alternative anchors may be used to mount the lights more securely. One (...Embeded) is suitable to be placed in mortar and the other (...Surface) may be surface mounted onto a #8 screw. There are files that make 1, 4, or 9 of these at a time.

The fins that fit into the bottom of the lamp are fairly tight some sanding at the tips might help.

The plates with the slots are used when embedding the anchors. I found it easier to cut a hole in some cardboard and, using the plate for support, put the anchor through the plate upside down through the cardboard and then pour the mortar over the anchor. The plate also keeps the fins clean.

title: RAM motorcycle mirrors or mirror mounts

description.text: These are small motorcycle mirrors that fit RAM mounts. You print these and then stick on 2-inch round blind-spot mirrors or 2 1/4 x 1 3/8-inch rectangle blind-spot mirrors. There are files for round and rectangle mirrors with KTM on them and files for plain round and rectangle mirrors (no logo). I found both style mirrors at Pep Boys Auto. I use these when I'm leading on an off-road ride, and I want to see my friends behind me without having to crane my neck around all day. They are not for street rides, really, but maybe. I use the short RAM arms with them usually so I don't bash my chest or helmet on it. A long or medium RAM arm will move them up and out more and might make them more useful for street rides. I Plasti-Dip the 1-inch RAM balls when finished to keep them on lock-down and reduce vibration. Enjoy and Braaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaap on!

Landing skid for F450 style quad. Designed in OpenSCAD. Latest version will always be on github: https://github.com/beckdac/f450_landing_skid

I used carbon fiber arrow shafts for the cross bars after stripping the fletching, nock, and tips, e.g. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PDAOHPQ . The padding is pipe insulation from the local hardware store wrapped with warning tape. Gives about 13.
5cm vertical landing clearance with 16cm width between skids.

Printed with 20% infill in PLA. The idea is that this should break first, absorbing the impact of a hard landing, and not your quad. The whole rig with arrow shafts and 3d printed parts weighs 64g (56 for the printed parts). I broke a set of skids in a 40 foot fall but the quad was fine, otherwise.

description.text: CT1012 clutch alignment tool.
This tool is useful for marking the center of a square, cylinder and rectangular objects

CENTER POINT MARKER DEVICE HISTORY:
In 2005 I invented and patented the Center Point Marker Device (US Patent No. 7,082,694). After spending $10,000 plus in attempting to market this tool device without success I gave up. I had two promising companies interested in it until the economy went south. My first prototype, which I still use today, was made on a commercial 3D printer. I have abandoned the patent and am herewith making the device public.
The following link is a video using the Center Point Marker Device. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=es7JblRYufE The following link is to the patent in Google Patents. (View this to see additional options) http://www.google.com/patents/about/7082694_Center_point_locator_device.html?id=oSJ6AAAAEBAJ DESCRIPTION:
The Center Point Marker Device is a simple tool for marking the center of an object quickly. It can mark the center of four different shapes: square, circular, rectangular and octangular. By placing a rubber band around the Control Knobs the device will hold to the object. My YouTube video shows marking four different parts. The accuracy is dependent on how well the parts are assembled. My commercially printed prototype had an accuracy of between 0.005 and 0.010 of an inch Note: Not all squares are square and not all cylinders or dowels are truly round, which can affect the accuracy tolerances. REQUIRED TOOLS AND HARDWARE:
3d Printer and Filament
Sanding sticks, files or/and emery boards
Drill Press
(1) Punch
(4) #3 x 3/8â€ Flat Head Sheet Metal Screws
Rubber Band INSTRUCTIONS:
Download the stl files. You can also download the dxf file created in AutoCAD if you wish to make changes or improvements. The PDF file has all the instructions, drawings and photoâ€™s for downloading. The expanded view of the device shows how the parts fit together.
You will need two of each part except the 4 Arm Base which one is required. Print the parts with the finest resolution you can. I had to do some sanding of the rough faces to have a smoother sliding motion. The fit of the pins and the knobs is critical. Other options can be used for the pins (cutlery rivets or?) if desired. The included design has been enlarged 20% over my original prototype and converted to metri. The size just fits my printer.
I attached the Rotating Jaws with #4 screws. The Male and Female pins also attach with #4 screws.
You can use your choice of a punch. I machined one from steel so I could add a spring. However, I also use an aluminum blind rivet for softer materials. Again the hole should be machined for snug sliding fit as this is critical to the accuracy. The point on the punch must also be at the true center. ASSEMBLY STEPS:
Dress the parts as needed. M
achine the punch hole in the 4 Arm Base part so your punch is snug and slides without falling out. The hole must be truly perpendicular for accuracy. Assemble the Right Angle Jaws to the 4 Arm Base using the Control Knobs. Remember they have to slide freely. The top faces of the Right Angle Jaws face each other. I use hot melt glue to secure the Control Knobs, that way I could remove if needed. Attach the 4 Arm Base and the Right Angle Jaws together using the Male and Female Pins as shown in the expanded drawing. Use #4 screws to attach the Pins together. Countersink the parts that receive the #3 screws.
Attach the Rotating Jaws to the Right Angle Jaws with #4 screws. Tighten only enough so the Rotating Jaws rotate freely If you are like me you may have to remake some parts. I have made two of this size and they work fine. I am happy to answer any question by email: [email protected] Also I would accept a small donation through PayPal: [email protected] Thanks for looking and good luck. Hugh Lyman

title: Fan holder for Trick Laser MAX METAL Platform

description.text:
Trick Laser makes an excellent aluminum platform for the Rostock MAX delta printer. The design opens up a lot of free space on the effector, enough to fit 2 (maybe 3) fans into depending on your hotend. This is an adapter that clicks onto the platform and holds the fans at an angle to blow the part.
The fans produce so much air that there is enough back blow to cool the hot end, so I recommend coating your heater block with RTV silicone to prevent that from happening.

title: MOAB - MOther of All fan Brackets

description.text:
An easy way to generate brackets to attach any fan to any PCB board. A list of pre-defined brackets included. The script was initially meant to generate fan brackets for the RAMPS board but I decided to make it fully customizable: it now allows you to create brackets that take fans of any size, snap onto PCB of any size, can have any height, but probably best of all features is that you can generate both mini-brackets (2 holes) as well as full brackets (4 holes, fully enclosed on two sides), to balance between saving plastic vs. rigidity and improved air flow.
While this was meant for PCBs, feel free to experiment it could probably be used for many other scenarios, for example to attach a fan to a NEMA17 motor or to space two PCBs by attaching brackets back to back, etc. UPDATE :
It can now generate PCB supports with no holes (example scenario: Raspberry Pi or Intel Galileo feet). Specific changes:
  • fan cutout (and the screw holes) can be removed entirely now to produce spacers or PCB feet
  • hex nuts resize with screw size (need to validate in practice)
  • cross-brace is configurable and can also be removed
    Note: If the fan is bigger than the PCB (for example when using an 80mm fan on RAMPS) the bracket will be generated with "wings" and the fan will attach on the outside of the bracket to those wings, otherwise the fan will attach on the inside.
    Additional benefit compared specifically to thing 138370: the brackets should now slide along the board without hitting the reset button and should also slide better along Arduino or RAMPs PCBs which have solder joints or connectors really close to the edge.

I typically print them out of PLA, 0.20 to 0.33 layer thickness. With these settings a bracket thickness of 3mm seems to get the best elasticity to snap-on to a RAMPS board and stay vibration free and still allow it to slide along the board.
Additional parts needed to build a cooling bracket:
  • a cooling fan (any size)
  • 4x screws and 4x nuts, typically M3 size, but actual diameter and length depends on the fan chosen.
    To build PCB slide-on covers or feet no additional parts needed.

print_settings.Notes:: To make Guitarz multi-color pause your machine and change filament at approx. 76% (11mm) and 96% (14mm) progress (with a 1mm raft)

title: Guitarz - Tunable and Playble Mini Guitars
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Just for fun...

Guitarz only need a couple of rubber (or stretchy nylon) bands to complete a playable, tuneable mini guitar that's styled after an electric guitar. Just pick he rubber band strings or strum away....

There is an internal cavity that has been designed in.to improve the sound. As with a real guitar, tuning is all important. Once you have tuned your Guitarz, you can play a basic tune on them. Obviously they aren't loud as a full size metal stringed guitar but with a bit of tuning they can deliver a surprising range of notes and even be strummed.

This is an easy and fun print. The body of Guitarz is almost hollow however there is a small amount of designed in permanent support structure so no support is required (for PLA prints). Using support could result in the body being filled, not hollow, which will affect the sound output. The hollow body, albeit a small area, makes a difference.

Preparing your Guitarz to play post print is easy.... just run 1 / 2 / 4 rubber bands (depending on what you have available) around the band slots in your Guitarz making sure each band follows its respective slot (Refer to the images provided).

Tension can be adjusted by wrapping the rubber band/s around the pins on the underside which will alter the note when the band is picked. Altering the position of the rubber bands around each end of your Guitarz will also affect the tension and note created when picked or strummed. Tuning can be a bit fiddly and variable (as rubber bands will stretch etc.) but easy to do with a bit of experience.

Obviously this will never match a real guitar but, as a fun 3D printed musical instrument, once you've played around with the band tensions it's surprising how readily you can play a few simple notes to make a tune.... and you can even strum them.

At standard scale Guitarz are 160mm in length. Scaling up is no problem but scaling down may make fitment of rubber bands and tuning difficult (...the slots will reduce in size)

To make Guitarz multi-color pause your machine and change filament at approx. 76% and 96% progress (with a 1mm raft)

Have fun with your Guitarz!

Please refer to the images and print settings for additional instructions.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs... and post images of your Guitarz in action!.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

3 Shells / 20% infill

Notes:

Easy print.... raft is recommended for ease of removal from the build plate. Make sure no support is used as it could build inside the hollow area of the Guitarz body.

To make Guitarz multi-color pause your machine and change filament at approx. 76% (11mm) and 96% (14mm) progress (with a 1mm raft)

Time to 'band' (....not string) your Guitarz!

Run 1 / 2 / 4 rubber bands (depending on what you have available) around the band slots in your Guitarz making sure each band follows its respective slot.

Tension can be adjusted by wrapping the rubber band/s around the pins on the underside which will alter the note when the band is picked. Altering the position of the rubber bands around each end of your Guitarz will also affect the tension and note created when picked or strummed. Tuning can be a bit fiddly and variable (as rubber bands will stretch etc.) but easy to do with a bit of experience.

Obviously this will never match a real guitar but, as a fun 3D printed musical instrument, once you've played around with the band tensions it's surprising how readily you can play a few simple notes to make a tune.... and you can even strum them.

Have fun with them!

print_settings.Notes:: Print in a way that works for you.

title: Isolating Printer Feet (D-Bot / V-Slot / Aluminium Extrusion) using Springs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I never knew what vibration was until I completed my D-Bot CoreXY machine. The structural integrity of my domicile was threatened when I initially ran it sat on the floor, so I designed some dampening feet that would be low cost to produce.

Note: I found these feet caused some issues with high speed/acceleration/jerk settings and am redesigning to include 7 springs each currently.

This is now my final complete design which I have printed, tested and have them installed and working well on my printer. I have changed the springs I am using (link below has been updated). These ones are slightly smaller and a bit firmer - they work great and I would be confident putting upto 10kg load on per foot, maybe more.

Each foot consists of:

1 x Printed 'Spring Feet Top.stl'
1 x Printed 'Spring Feet Bottom.stl'
4 x Springs (http://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-printer-accessories-Ultimaker-2-UM2-spring-fine-print-platform-edging-1-2-15mm-for-UM2/32606455778.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.108.bIz7v1) - buy 1 pack and you can make 7.5 feet)
1 x 3M 'Bumpon' adhesive rubber foot circular/flat 20mm x 2mm (or cut your own from cork, etc.)

Assembly should be pretty self explanatory from the renders...

  1. Prepare the bottom part by placing 4x springs in the holes. Springs should fit relatively snugly on their own and the assembled foot will easily hold together without additional adhesive.

  2. Put M5 cap head bolt into the hole in the top of the top part (you may need to drill out the hole depending how accurately your print turned out - but with a bit of force you should get the thread through and head in the recess without this). If printing ABS scale up to allow for shrinkage.

  3. Line up springs with top piece and push everything together.

  4. Attach to bottom of printer/equipment using an allen key through the hole in the bottom of the bottom part.

  5. Place 3M bumpon foot into recess on the very bottom.

  6. Done

Printer:

D-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print in a way that works for you.

comments.text: Why is your printer vibrating so much? How fast are you printing?
comments.author: spauda01

comments.text: It's not unusually noisy when you are in the same room, but the floor below it is echoing around (we have wooden hard floors). As I intend to set up the printer in a room adjacent to where we sleep, I don't want this vibration being transferred to the workbench it is sat on, then through the floor, so this is a decoupling measure.
comments.author: spauda01

comments.text: Have you tried turning down acceleration and jerk settings
comments.author: beepbeep

comments.text: I'm waiting to change out the shims in the wheels to metal before anything else, as I think this is the issue right now - the printed shims (the way they turned out on my printer) don't allow for the wheels to be tight to the extrusion and still let things move smoothly, so I have a situation where I either have the wheels unable to rotate or the gantry has loads of play in it. I think this must be inviting resonance in some way.
comments.author: spauda01

DONT FORGET TO WATCH THE HOWTO VIDEO!!!!

If you need the L.O.A.D.E.R for your PTW mags?! Follow this link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2355628

Airsoft Speedloader for m4 Magazines and more with adapters ( check out my things),
It holds about 2000BBs at once, loading fast, easy and reliable, check out the howto make this thing and how it performs in the videos below.
Description of how to print the parts is included in the download as well a list of extra parts you will need.
spread the word, keep inventing and creating!

!!!UPDATE14.02.2017!!!

After Using the Loader for quite a Time now there was not much to change or complain.
The only think bothering me was that the BB chamber was getting empty quite fast so I created a bigger chamber, also I reinforced the actual design a lot!!

For comfort I added a Grip on the side so its easier to hold the loader and the magazine while loading.

!!!!UPDATE18.02.2017!!!!

Yet another update, this time its an additional UNLOADER on the BB chamber cover.
The only thing you need is a 40mm long Aluminium tube with a outer diameter of 10 and a inner diameter of 8. Now you are able to unload every mag within a split second to preserve the magazine spring.

!!!UPDATE22.02.2017!!!
New Hand crank with turn able knob added for even smother and easier loading.

!!!UPDATE 01.03.2017!!!
The grip on the side wasnt working as expected, replaced with a more common, easier and better working design on both sides. Reinforced and much bigger BB Chamber, the BB Cover with UNLOADER comes now with a silica gel compartment. New designed Magcatch which should hold the magazine much more stable and safe.

!!!UPDATE09.06.2017!!!
NEW ALPHA upgraded parts like a new turbine wheel enables you to load 12 BBs instead of 8 with one turn.
Also the turbine housing has a new design and was strongly reinforced
The BB chamber was adapted to the new turbin housing and altered so it fits much better right off from the printer without much postwork.

!!!UPDATE 09.02.2018!!!

New modified version of the M4 magazine adapter from Bernd Brandenburg alias "Kolbenkopf" He had problems as his Magazines were way to tight in the adapter so he modified it to fit perfectly with slightly bigger produced magazine types.
Special Thanks to him for his great work.

title: RRD Hall Effect Sensor Endstop Case for PrintrBot LC/PLUS Z axis

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/iYmJQqxuRQk Here we have a tiny case for a hall effect sensor end stop for a Printrbot LC/PLUS. It's designed to attach to the stock end stop holes with the stock screws, then for the PCB to screw on to the caase with M3 screws. May need some adjustment on the holes depending on your machine. The notch underneath is so you can put the wiring back through the stock hole into the base of the machine. This endstop has on the back "designed by rrd" and is available from BilbyCNC from their online store. It is designed to plug straight onto the Printrboard and happily run. https://www.bilbycnc.com.au/DispCat.asp?CatID=11&SubCatID=94 Third from the bottom In addition to this, you will need to invert the end stop, as the hall effect sensor works the opposite way to a microswitch, so it is closed until open, microswitch is open until closed.

description.text:
I would love to keep sharing my projects with all of you. If you enjoy with my designs, I invite you to become a patron, you will get early access to my designs and exclusive content! Also, you can help with a small donation.

Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

I recently started working with laser cutting machines and I realized some panels were thrown away when they could still be used. I took those small parts and used them to create a small collection of 3D printer miniatures to decorate a Fab Lab or any maker's house!

The miniatures are 7cm high (width vary depending on the model). Source files are optimized for laser cutting with 3mm plywood. Also, as we are talking about 3D printers (!!!), I've created a 3D printable version which is the same as the laser cut design.

Feel free to modify any design, customize it or create your own 3D printer miniature!

Sitting labrador
A very special Fish

I have been flying a Slow Stick to practice landings and to build up my flying skills while keeping costs low. My last change was to outfit it with a V-tail but now I need to begin upgrading my aileron skills. I decided to build a wing using Dollar Tree foam board but with internal reinforcements. This servo mount with fairings is a result of that design episode.

The mount was originally designed to wrap completely around a 9G servo and attach with 2 2mm screws. The mount had a lower flange to extend from the outer skin of the foam board to the inner skin to allow plenty of bonding area to the foam with Gorilla Glue. But, when I went to insert the servo it wouldn’t fit. The servo leads would go through the opening and when I tried to tip the servo it was too long to fit. I removed enough material to allow the servo to tip through the opening which removed the AFT mounting hole. I added a pair of holes on each side assuming I would grow a small strap to bridge across the servo ear. Looking at the finished assembly with the servo mounted in the mounting plate made me realize I could fair the servo If I created a forward and aft fairing detail.

The details were printed in ABS and the fasteners holes tapped for a 2mm screw (button head). After assembling the servo, mount and 2 fairings I am still amazed as to how small it is. Not to mention the difficulty of handling 2mm screws with my fat fingers. The 2 diagonal grooves in the forward fairing are a guide used when installing the control horn to the servo. The extreme angle shows the limiting angle to achieve the greatest aileron differential.

title: Lab plate vortex/shaker from a 140 mm fan

description.text:
I wanted an agitator that could do a bunch of different jobs in the lab, from mixing samples overnight to cleaning grinding beads in bleach. I also wanted to achieve this with a minimum of effort (and wanted others with only basic electronics experience to be able to do the same), so I put this together from a 140 mm computer fan and a multi-voltage power adaptor.

This tool performs two major lab functions: vortexing samples and vibrating the heck out of samples. The platform comfortably fits a 96-well plate, or one of those large square tube racks. You can just as easily use this agitator to mix up hobby paints or food colours.

Video demonstration of this Thing here.

This design is a fancier version of the DIY paint shaker described by Angry Dwarf! Miniatures.

How to use it

You have two ways of adjusting the machine to get it to do what you want: changing the input voltage via the power adaptor, and changing where the weight is located on the fan blade.

Having the weight closer to the center of the fan creates vibration. This is how your phone generates its vibrations, for example.

Moving the weight away from the center of the fan creates slow, circular oscillations, and this is what you want for mixing and vortexing.

I find that the best way to use the machine is to start it at the highest voltage/fastest speed, and then turn it down until you have the result that you want. Especially when your goal is to vortex samples, there's something about working backwards like this that helps the vortex motion establish itself.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

At least 25%

Notes:

Print all items in the orientation I've provided them. The spring mounts, in particular, must be printed horizontally so that they don't snap when you're fitting them into the springs.

Bill of Materials

Tools

  • A long-stemmed screwdriver that can fit through the fan's mounting holes
  • Hot glue gun

Printed components

  • 1 × agitator base.stl
  • 1 × agitator platform.stl
  • 8 × agitator spring mount.stl

For the frame assembly

  • 4 × 9×35 mm compression spring (AliExpress)
  • 4 × self-adhesive rubber feet (AliExpress)

For the moving parts

  • 1 × 140 mm computer fan
  • 8 × standard PC fan screw
  • 2 × neodymium magnets (or any other weight of 2–4 grams)
  • 1 × 3.5 mm female jack (AliExpress Example 1 or Example 2)
  • 1 × multi-voltage power adapter (mine delivers 3–12 V with a maximum of 800 mA).

For the platform

  • 4 × each of nylon nuts, standoffs, washers, and screws (AliExpress)
  • Grippy surface, e.g. rubber kitchen mat.

Assembly

  1. Screw 4 spring mounts onto one side of the fan, and the remaining 4 onto the printed base.
    • The fan's orientation isn't important.
    • The flat faces of the spring mounts should be pointing out to the corners of the base and fan.
  2. Attach the counterweight to one of the fan's blades. I used magnets (total weight 4 g) so that I can adjust their position at any time.
    • Heavier weights need to be closer to the center, or else the agitator will be thrown around during use.
    • You may need to hot-glue the weights in place.
  3. Mount nylon stand-offs to the screw holes on the opposite face of the computer fan.
    • These stand-offs keep the printed platform away from the fan blades in case your weights protrude.
  4. Place the printed platform on top of the standoffs, and secure with a washer and screw. The platform will be pulled taut.
  5. Push the springs onto the protruding spring mounts to mate the fan and base together.
  6. Attach the self-adhesive rubber feet to the printed base.

Electronics

Your fan has 2 or 3 wires; red, black, and maybe yellow. Yellow can be ignored; it controls fan speed when connected to a computer, but we are using the multi-voltage power supply for that.

I wired my fan directly to a 3.5 mm female jack so that I could put a 3.5 mm male on my multi-voltage adapter and plug it straight in. The female jack fits into a mounting hole in the printed base.

Optional improvements

You can place a rubber mat on your platform like I did, which serves to hold the items being mixed and also silence their tapping against the platform.

However, I recommend reusable double-sided mounting strips to really hold stuff down. I use this on my magnetic stirrer and it's fantastic, and if it loses its stickiness you can just wash it to bring it back.
